channel.title: Tdss botnet
channel.description:
[size=24pt]Indestructible TDSS botnet is spotted[/size]
LOCK DOWN YOUR COMPUTERS and hide your womenfolk and kids, there is a new botnet in town and it sounds like the worst one yet. According to the Russian security pros at Kaspersky the botnet, which it's given the name TDSS, is particularly sophisticated, and thus it represents a particularly significant threat. "The malware detected by Kaspersky Anti-Virus as TDSS is the most sophisticated threat today," reports the firm in a new warning about the botnet. "TDSS uses a range of methods to evade signature, heuristic, and proactive detection, and uses encryption to facilitate communication between its bots and the botnet command and control center. TDSS also has a powerful rootkit component, which allows it to conceal the presence of any other types of malware in the system."
Read more: http://www.theinquirer.net/inquirer/news/2083193/indestructible-tdss-botnet-spotted#ixzz1QmwmwnAA

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

mopman i want to be inside you

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Yes, those are bugs, as is the flaw of Windows you discussed - or did you think that was a feature?

Windows is “designed” to do the same thing Linux is, and they’ve both had their successes and failures.

This blind refusal to accept that open source software ever has any flaws and misguided hatred of proprietary software with random bullshit facts is why the open source community was laughed at for so long and has had such a fight to be taken seriously, by the way.

I am curious how you’re going to twist this to make it seem like the kernel bugs I linked to and the Windows one are any different. Both situations are kernel level bugs that allow usermode applications to cause crashes in extreme situations. They’re exactly the fkn same.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Those are bugs (that have all been fixed, by the looks of it), windows is designed to let this stuff happen by default, due to flaws in user applications, as opposed to specially crafted applications made specifically to exploit bugs. You brought up another flaw inherent to windows and other closed source operating systems, anyone can find these bugs in Linux and fix them, instead of waiting potentially years or forever for the vendor to fix them.

Yes, I know NTFS is journalled, that’s why I didn’t list it.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

The issue is that the Linux kernel (or any decent OS, really) can’t be crashed by a user application

http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2010-4165
http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2011-2022
http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2011-1770
http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2011-2534
http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2010-4805
http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2011-1581
http://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2010-4251

Also, NTFS is journalled. FAT32 is deprecated. By that logic, Linux has the same problem if people use ext2.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

Oh it’s possible, in the same way that its possible with a kernel panic on any OS. But Linux doesn’t have those apparently, since its kernel is self aware and can always figure out what to do in any situation.

Well, now you’re getting into a realm where the file system in use matters, if the kernel panics or your computer loses power. Generally Linux filesystems use a journal and/or other things to try to recover from things like that, and are less likely to crap out than say, fat32.

That wasn’t the issue though. The issue is that the Linux kernel (or any decent OS, really) can’t be crashed by a user application, where as that happens all the time under windows, as shown above, even by visiting a web page.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Doesn’t anyone remember moparisthebest.com/no.html? If you visited it in IE6 it would make your computer die with a blue screen of death instantly, from a web page!

Crashed many school computers with this back in the day.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Oh it’s possible, in the same way that its possible with a kernel panic on any OS. But Linux doesn’t have those apparently, since its kernel is self aware and can always figure out what to do in any situation.

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Really? I’ve had many, many BSODs but never had one corrupt files or do any damage to my system.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

I’m sure to the user that just lost their session, the fact that their kernel is chugging along fine is very comforting.

It is, because their hard drive isn’t corrupted, and everything else they had running wasn’t hurt. As opposed to windows where a BSOD often corrupts your hard drive or at least individual files.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

eczema3:

I don’t know what kind of piss poor security you had jme, but my PC asks me if I want to do something before it happens, and it can’t be escaped. You only really get affected if you click yes to the “YOUR PC IS INFECTED WITH 543523435234 VIRUSES AND YOU NEED TO INSTALL THIS DODGY SOFTWARE TO FIX IT” adverts, or bullshit like that.

I love how the windows XP look and feel is displayed on mine, despite my use of linux. I can never stop laughing at that.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That’s right, but a flaw in a linux application could never take down the entire operating system, so how badly is windows programmed if a flaw in how a web page is parsed can take down the entire computer?

It’s still there:
view-source:https://www.moparisthebest.com/no.html
For the curious, it’s nothing to do with the image, just the width and height tags, when they are out of range, BSOD.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

It wasn’t limited to IE either, the Acrobat dropper ads worked on Firefox and probably any other browser that had an Acrobat plugin.

For some reason people think that if you have an antivirus, vulnerabilities in software don’t exist anymore.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

eczema3:

I don’t know what kind of piss poor security you had jme, but my PC asks me if I want to do something before it happens, and it can’t be escaped. You only really get affected if you click yes to the “YOUR PC IS INFECTED WITH 543523435234 VIRUSES AND YOU NEED TO INSTALL THIS DODGY SOFTWARE TO FIX IT” adverts, or bullshit like that.

I am speaking with no third party security running. Of course I wouldn’t click on those. My pc does that too, since I’ve upgraded to win7. But there were many different exploits on pages that could execute programs on your computer with xp.

Look at mopmans link for example.

Read full topic

item.title: Tdss botnet
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

You sure can get infected by visiting a webpage. Even the ads in webpages you trust can have exploits in them. Can’t speak for the latest IE running on win7, but go use ie on winxp. Websites for song lyrics will infect you, websites for serial numbers etc will definitely infect you, and ive been infected immediately by visiting thepiratebay because of some malicious advertisements. In almost all cases, it installs rogue anti-virus software.

Read full topic
